review I LOVE ROMAN FEVER! Though I can be impartial to short stories, when I read this for class, I fell in love with it. I think I connect with it most bec I LOVE ROMAN FEVER! Though I can be impartial to short stories, when I read this for class, I fell in love with it. I think I connect with it most because I have a childhood friend who always seemed to have everything, every opportunity, everything handed to her, and she walked all over her friends, including me, taking every advantage that came her way. So, when I read this story, I couldn't help but laugh, thinking Mrs. Ansley had the perfect revenge. I have no interest in seeking my own vengeance, but it was almost like just reading the story, and making the connection that I did, was my own little way of finally getting the upper hand. ...more

review I've read this three times now, in three different translations. This was by far the most easily accessible version I've read and it made it a breeze I've read this three times now, in three different translations. This was by far the most easily accessible version I've read and it made it a breeze to get through. Imagine that...The Iliad...a breeze. The professor I had who used this text may have had an influence in my love of this book, but really, the first two times I read it, I felt like I struggled. ...more

review We actually used this book as a textbook for a class I took on the Vietnam War. Being a child of the eighties, I was not around for the war, and it wa We actually used this book as a textbook for a class I took on the Vietnam War. Being a child of the eighties, I was not around for the war, and it was just a brief lesson in history class, if that. This book changed me. I began reading far ahead of the class, and finished the book long before the semester was over. I watched every movie I could find on the subject. In short, this book brought a terrible war to life for me, and made it a part of MY history, instead of just world history. ...more

review Though many people (especially women) Heathcliffe as some dark and brooding handsome man, I never saw the attraction. I could not connect with the boo Though many people (especially women) Heathcliffe as some dark and brooding handsome man, I never saw the attraction. I could not connect with the book having seen Heathcliffe for exactly what he was. I felt bogged down all the dreariness of the Heights and was absolutely depressed when I finished it. I understand why this book is assigned reading, but maybe it should be given out with a bottle of Prozac. ...more
